text:
Finding a parking spot can be a challenge at first, but once you arrive at this expansive playing field, it's well worth the effort. The wide-open, grass-carpeted flying zone under a clear sky makes for an incredible FPV experience. Even after a crash, our drone sustained little to no damage, thanks to the soft landing surface.

The hut provides ample shade, making it a comfortable spot to operate from. Once you're done flying, you can head back to the Create Tower area, where eateries remain open even on weekends.

For those driving, you can park at the NUS Create Tower car park and follow the designated path. Thereâ€™s a gate in the fenced-up area that appears to be open at all times. The walk from the car park to the southern end of the flying zone took me about seven minutes. Refer to my map for the locations.
Another authorized drone flying are in Singapore, you can train your drone or toy planes. But dont have much facilities. If you flying a drone there is not much sceneric views for taking photos.
Good place for learning flying drone, but the flying path within small area. No parking lot best to take public transport

Not quite accessible as the nearest carpark are at the HDB blocks about 15min walk away. And if you are lugging your equipment backpack you will be all sweaty by the time you get there.
The place is hilly and does not have much amenities other than a few tables. There are huts around but again they are another few minutes hike away.
Nothing very scenic here if you want to take pictures. This place is more for those who want to practice moves or stunts. Fixed wings, helicopters, FPV. Camera drone pilots will be disappointed.

Ever feel like some projects are just destined to be duds?  You know, the ones built in the middle of nowhere, with no way to get there?  No parking, no entrance, not even a bike path in sight.  What's the point of a fancy new thing if it's just going to sit there unused?  Talk about a waste of tax money. Which scholar plan this?
